sen.e: In those days, as his family, the house of mayor, might have become ruined in the confusion after the collapse of Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun,) he was fostered by a family of secondhand shop (or in another opinion, a vegetable store) in Yotsuya immediately after birth; however, his sister felt pity for him, who was left sleeping among the goods until late at night, and took him back to home.

sen.j: 子規が手がけた漢詩や俳句などの文集『七草集』が学友らの間で回覧されたとき、漱石がその批評を巻末に漢文で書いたことから、本格的な友情が始まる。
sen.e: When "Nanakusashu," a collection of Shiki's works including Chinese-style poem and haiku, was passed round the classmates, Soseki added his comment in Chinese at the end of the collection, which was the beginning of real friendship between Shiki and Soseki.

sen.j: このときに初めて漱石という号を使う。

sen.j: 漱石の名は、唐代の『晋書』にある故事「漱石枕流」（石に漱〔くちすす〕ぎ流れに枕す）から取ったもので、負け惜しみの強いこと、変わり者の例えである。
sen.e: The name 'Soseki' originated from 'Soseki Chinryu' (rinsing his mouth with a stone and resting his head on a pillow of flowing water,) a phrase from a historical event written in "Shinjo" in the Tang dynasty, which is a simile of 'bad loser' and 'perverse person.'

sen.j: 「漱石」は子規の数多いペンネームのうちの一つであったが、のちに漱石は子規からこれを譲り受けている。

sen.e: In November of the same year, relationship between Soseki and Shiki was getting closer through several occasions including that Soseki asked Shiki to criticize his "Bokusetsuroku," an account of a journey to Awa Province (Boso Peninsula) written in Chinese.

sen.j: 明治23年（1890年）、創設間もなかった帝国大学（後に東京大学）英文科に入学。
sen.e: In 1890, Soseki entered the English Literature Department of Teikoku University (later Tokyo University,) which had just been founded.

sen.j: この頃から厭世主義、神経衰弱 (精神疾患)に陥り始めたともいわれる。
sen.e: It is considered to be this period that Soseki began to be pessimistic and suffer from nervous breakdown (psychiatric disorder.)

sen.j: 先立つ明治20年（1887年）の3月に長兄・大助と死別。

sen.j: 同年6月に次兄・栄之助と死別。
sen.e: In June in the same year, he lost his next oldest brother Einosuke.

sen.j: さらに直後の明治24年（1891年）には三兄・和三郎の妻の登世と死別と次々に近親者を亡くした事も影響している。
sen.e: Soon after in 1891, he lost Tose, the wife of his third oldest brother Wasaburo; his loss of these close relatives one after another might have affected his state of mind.

sen.j: 漱石は登世に恋心を抱いていたとも言われ、心に深い傷をうけ、登世に対する気持ちをしたためた句を何十首も詠んでいる。
sen.e: Soseki was deeply hurt by the death of Tose and composed dozens of haiku to express his feeling about her, as it is said that he loved her.

sen.j: 翌年、特待生に選ばれ、J・M・ディクソン教授の依頼で『方丈記』の英訳などする。
sen.e: In the next year, he was given a scholarship, and in response to a request from Professor J. M. Dixon, he translated "Hojoki" into English.

sen.j: 明治25年（1892年）、兵役を逃れるために分家し、貸費生であったため、北海道に籍を移す。
sen.e: In 1892, he established a branch family to evade conscription, and moved his registered address to Hokkaido as he was a scholarship student.

sen.j: 同年5月あたりから東京専門学校（現在の早稲田大学）の講師をしてみずから学費を稼ぎはじめる。
sen.e: Around May in the same year, he started to earn his school fees by working as an instructor at Tokyo Senmongakko (present Waseda University.)

sen.j: 漱石と子規は早稲田の辺を一緒に散歩することもままあり、その様を子規は自らの随筆『墨汁一滴』で「この時余が驚いた事は漱石は我々が平生喰ふ所の米はこの苗の実である事を知らなかったといふ事である」と述べている。
sen.e: Soseki and Shiki often took a stroll around Waseda; Shiki mentioned the stroll with Soseki in his essay "Bokuju Itteki," 'I was surprised to find that Soseki did not know rice, which we eat everyday, are seeds of these rice plants.'

sen.j: 7月7日、大学の夏期休業を利用して、松山に帰省する子規と共に、初めての関西方面の旅に出る。
sen.e: On July 7, Soseki took advantage of the summer vacation of the university to leave for Kansai to travel for the first time, accompanying Shiki who were returning home in Matsumaya.

sen.j: 夜行列車で新橋を経ち、8日に京都に到着して二泊し、10日神戸で子規と別れて11日に岡山に到着する。
sen.e: They left Shinbashi on a night train; on July 8, arrived at Kyoto and stayed there over two nights; on 10, Soseki parted from Shiki at Kobe; and on 11, arrived at Okayama.

sen.j: 岡山では、次兄・栄之助の妻であった小勝の実家、片岡機邸に1ヶ月あまり逗留する。
sen.e: In Okayama, he stayed at the house of Hazumu KATAOKA, the father of Okatsu, the wife of his second oldest brother Einosuke, about a month.

sen.j: この間、7月19日、松山の子規から、学年末試験に落第したので退学すると記した手紙が届く。
sen.e: On July 19, during this stay, Soseki received a letter from Shiki in Matsuyama saying that he would leave the school because he had failed the annual examinations.

sen.e: In the afternoon on that day, Soseki sent a letter to Shiki to prompt him to change the decision by adding a haiku 'Nakunaraba Mangetsu ni nake Hototogisu' (Night cuckoo, if you cry, Cry to the full moon.)

sen.j: その後、8月10日、岡山を立ち、松山の子規の元に向かう。
sen.e: On August 10, Soseki left Okayama to visit Shiki in Matsuyama.

sen.j: 子規の家で、後に漱石を職業作家の道へ誘うことになる当時15歳の高浜虚子と出会う。
sen.e: At Shiki's house, Soseki became acquainted with fifteen-year-old Kyoshi TAKAHAMA, who would encourage Soseki to be a professional writer later.

sen.j: 明治26年（1893年）、帝国大学を卒業し、東京教育大学の英語教師になるも、日本人が英文学を学ぶことに違和感を覚え始める。
sen.e: In 1893, he graduated from Teikoku University and became an English teacher at Tokyo Kyoiku University; however, he had an odd feeling about the Japanese studying the English literature.

sen.j: 前述の2年前の失恋もどきの事件や翌年発覚する肺結核も重なり、極度の神経衰弱 (精神疾患)、強迫観念にかられるようになる。
sen.e: Being affected by the above-mentioned incident of lost love in two years before accompanied by tuberculosis of the lungs to be found in the next year, he became suffered from extreme nervous breakdown (psychiatric disorder) and an obsession.

sen.j: その後、鎌倉市の円覚寺で参禅をするなどして治療をはかるも効果は得られなかった。
sen.e: Later, he tried some remedies including practicing Zen at Enkaku-ji Temple in Kamakura City in vain.

sen.j: 明治28年（1895年）、東京から逃げるように高等師範学校を辞職し、菅虎雄の斡旋で愛媛県尋常中学校（現在の愛媛県立松山東高等学校）に赴任する。
sen.e: In 1895, like fleeing from Tokyo, Soseki resigned Kotoshihangakko and left for his new post in Ehime prefectural Jinjo chugakko (present Ehime prefectural Matsuyamahigashi senior high school) through the good offices of Torao SUGA.

sen.j: ちなみに、松山市は子規の故郷であり、2ヶ月あまり静養していた。
sen.e: Since Matsuyama City was Shiki's hometown, Soseki stayed there for two months for a rest.

sen.j: この頃、子規とともに俳句に精進し、数々の佳作を残している。

sen.j: 明治29年（1896年）、熊本県第五高等学校 (旧制)（熊本大学の前身）の英語教師に赴任後、親族の勧めもあり貴族院書記官長中根重一の長女夏目鏡子と結婚をするが、3年目に鏡子は慣れない環境と流産のためヒステリー症が激しくなり白川 (熊本県)井川淵に投身を図るなど順風満帆な夫婦生活とはいかなかった。
sen.e: In 1896, after becoming an English teacher at Kumamoto prefectural daigo kotogakko (predecessor of Kumamoto University,) he married Kyoko, the oldest daughter of Juichi NAKANE, the Chief Secretary of the House of Peers, as recommended by his relatives, but his married life was not favorable; in the third year of their marriage, Kyoko suffered from so serious hysteria due to the environment she could not accustomed to accompanied by a miscarriage that she attempted to drown herself in Ikawabuchi of Shirakawa river in Kumamoto.

sen.j: 家庭面以外では、この頃漱石は俳壇でも活躍し、名声を確保していく。
sen.e: Except for family life, Soseki was as successful as being active in haiku circles and won fame.

sen.j: 明治33年（1900年）5月、文部省より英文学研究のため英国留学を命ぜられる。
sen.e: In May 1900, Soseki was ordered to study English literature in England by the Ministry of Education.

sen.j: ジョージ・メレディスやチャールズ・ディケンズをよく読みあさった。
sen.e: Soseki voraciously read books of George Meredith and Charles Dickens.
Soseki voraciously read books of George Meredith and Charles Dickens.

sen.j: 『永日小品』にも出てくるシェイクスピア研究家のウィリアム・クレイグの個人教授を受けたり、『文学論』の研究にいそしんだりするが、英文学研究への違和感がぶりかえし神経衰弱に陥り始める。
sen.e: Soseki received private tuition by William Craig, a Shakespeare scholar, whom Soseki described in "Eijitsu Shohin," and developed his theory of literature to be published as "Bungakuron"; however, he was obsessed by the odd feeling about the Japanese studying English literature again and relapsed into nervous breakdown.

sen.j: また東洋人であることでいわれなき人種差別を受け傷心し、研究が進まない苛立ちも重なったのか、何度も下宿を転々とする。
sen.e: He changed his boarding house frequently because he was hurt by racial discrimination as an Oriental person for nothing, which might have been accompanied by frustration in his study.

sen.j: 明治34年（1901年）、化学者の池田菊苗と2ヶ月間同居することで新たな刺激を受け、下宿に一人こもり研究に没頭しはじめる。
sen.e: In 1901, as he began sharing a room with a chemist Kikunae IKEDA for two months, he was stimulated and immersed himself in study alone in the boarding house.

sen.e: During that period, Soseki kept his associations with the other Japanese students in England to a minimum, and reputed to be 'suffered from mental disorder' among them.

sen.j: これを文部省が耳にし、急遽帰国が命じられる。
sen.e: That reputation reached the Ministry of Education and Soseki was ordered to return to Japan.

sen.j: 帰国後、漱石は第一高等学校と東京帝国大学から講師として招かれる。

sen.e: Soseki's works are categorized in the Yoyuha school, which was in contrast with the naturalist literature, the mainstream of literature in those days, because his novels have full of 'Teikai shumi,' coined by Soseki, which means dilettantism to be relaxed in thinking one's life instead of occupied with mundane affairs.

sen.j: 漱石は、歳を重ねるごとに病気がちとなり、肺結核、トラホーム、神経衰弱、痔、糖尿病、命取りとなった胃潰瘍まで、多数の病気を抱えていた。
sen.e: Soseki became sickly as he was getting older and had a lot of diseases like tuberculosis of the lungs, trachoma, nervous breakdown, hemorrhoids, diabetes, and gastric ulcer, of which he died.
Soseki became sickly as he was getting older and had a lot of diseases, including tuberculosis of the lungs, trachoma, nervous breakdown, hemorrhoids, diabetes, and gastric ulcer, of which he died.
Soseki became sickly as he was getting older and had a lot of diseases, including tuberculosis of the lungs, trachoma, nervous breakdown, hemorrhoids, diabetes, and gastric ulcer, of which he died.

sen.j: 『硝子戸の中』のように直接自身の病気に言及した作品以外にも、『吾輩は猫である』の苦沙弥先生が胃弱だったり、『明暗』が痔の診察の場面で始まっていたりするなど、小説にも自身の病気を下敷きにした描写がみられる。
sen.e: A lot of descriptions of illnesses appear not only in his works mentioning his illnesses like "Garasudo no naka" but also in his novels like "Wagahai wa neko dearu", in which Mister Kushami suffers from dyspepsia, "Meian", the opening scene of which is diagnosis of hemorrhoids, and so on.

sen.cmt: カンマ位置移動しました。

sen.j: 「秋風やひびの入りたる胃の袋」など、病気を題材にした句も多数ある。
sen.e: He composed a lot of haiku on his illnesses like 'Akikazeya Hibi no iritaru I no fukuro.'
He composed a lot of haiku on his illnesses, such as 'Akikazeya Hibi no iritaru I no fukuro.'
He composed a lot of haiku on his illnesses, such as 'Akikazeya Hibi no iritaru I no fukuro' (The autumn wind blows, and my stomach aches).
sen.cmt: 英語で意味を補足しました。

sen.j: 下戸だったが、胃弱であるにもかかわらずビーフステーキや中華料理などの脂っこい食事を好み、療養中には当時、貴重品だったアイスクリームを欲しがり周囲を困らせたこともある。
sen.e: He did not drink alcohol but was fond of greasy foods like beef steak and Chinese food, and during the convalescence, he troubled those around him by demanding ice cream, which was rare in those days.

He did not drink alcohol but was fond of greasy foods like beef steak and Chinese food, and during the convalescence, he troubled those around him by demanding ice cream, which was rare in those days.

sen.j: 当時出回り始めたジャムもお気に入りで毎日のように舐め、医師に止められるほどだったという（「吾輩は-」には1ヶ月に8缶も舐めたとの記述がある）。
sen.e: As Jam appeared on the market in those days, he also loved Jam so badly that he ate it everyday and was advised by the doctor to stop that (there is a description that Mister Kushami eats eight cans of Jam a month in "Wagahai wa neko dearu.")

sen.cmt: ピリオド位置移動しました。

sen.j: 胃弱が原因で頻繁に放屁をしたが、その音が破れ障子に風が吹き付ける音にそっくりだったことから、破障子なる落款を作り、使用していたことがある。
sen.e: He frequently broke wind because of his dyspepsia, and it sounded like wind blowing through a broken paper door so that he used Broken Paper Door as his signature for a while.
He frequently broke wind because of his dyspepsia, and it sounded like wind blowing through a broken paper door, so that for a while he used Broken Paper Door as his signature.

sen.j: 一般的に全く知られていないことであるが、漱石は天然痘にかかっており、自分の容姿に劣等感を抱いていた。
sen.e: Although it is not generally known, Soseki contracted smallpox, and because of the scars, he had a sense of inferiority about his appearance.
Although it is not generally known, Soseki contracted smallpox, and because of the scars, he had a sense of inferiority about his appearance.

sen.j: しかし写真家が気をきかせたりしたため、今残っている写真にはその跡が見受けられない。
sen.e: Photographers were considerate enough and no scars can be recognized on his face in photographs.
Photographers were considerate enough and no scars can be recognized on his face in photographs.

tit.j: 精神医学上の研究対象

sen.j: 漱石は、生前に神経衰弱やうつ病を患っているが、このことが当時のエリート層の一員であり、最上級のインテリでもあった漱石の生涯および作品に対して如何に影響を及ぼしているのかが、精神医学者の格好の研究対象となっており、実際にこれを主題としたいくつかの学術論文が発表されている。
sen.e: Psychiatrists regard it an ideal subject that how nervous breakdown and depression influenced on the life and works of Soseki, who was in the best and brightest in those days and one of the most intellectual persons in Japan; in fact, several treatises on the subject have been presented.

Psychiatrists regard it an ideal subject the way in which nervous breakdown and depression influenced the life and works of Soseki, who was among the best and brightest in those days and one of the most intellectual persons in Japan; in fact, several treatises on the subject have been presented.

Psychiatrists regard it an ideal subject the way in which nervous breakdown and depression influenced the life and works of Soseki, who was among the best and brightest in those days and one of the most intellectual persons in Japan; in fact, several treatises on the subject have been presented.

sen.j: 「晩年の漱石は修善寺の大患を経て心境的な変化に至った」とは、後の多くの批評家、研究家によって語られた論評である。
sen.e: A lot of critics and scholars said that 'In his later years, Soseki reached a certain state of mind through the experience of Shuzenji no Taikan.'
A lot of critics and scholars said that 'In his later years, Soseki reached a certain state of mind through the experience of Shuzenji no Taikan.'
A lot of critics and scholars said that 'In his later years, Soseki reached a certain state of mind through the experience of Shuzenji no Taikan.'

sen.j: また、この心境を表す漱石自身の言葉として「則天去私」という語句が広く知られ、広辞苑にも紹介されている。
sen.e: Sokutenkyoshi', which is contained in Kojien, is widely known as a word made by Soseki to express that state of mind.
Sokutenkyoshi', which is contained in Kojien, is widely known as a word coined by Soseki to express that state of mind.
Sokutenkyoshi,' which is contained in Kojien, is widely known as a word coined by Soseki to express that state of mind.
sen.cmt: カンマ位置移動しました。

sen.j: しかしながら、この「則天去私」という語は漱石自身が文章に残した訳ではなく、漱石の発言を弟子達が書き残したものであり、その意味は必ずしも明確ではない（人が生きるうえでの指針のように捉える説と、創作上の態度と捉える説などがある）。
sen.e: The word 'Sokutenkyoshi' was not written by Soseki in his sentences, but dictated by his disciples, therefore, its meaning is not very clear (according to an opinion, it is understood as a guiding principle for human life, and according to another opinion, it is understood as an attitude in creation.)

sen.j: 故人を神格化し、権威を与えるように使われてきた語だとする説もある。
sen.e: There is an opinion that the word has been used to deifying and authorizing Soseki.

sen.j: 夏目漱石の作品には、順序の入れ替え、当て字等言葉遊びの多用が見られる。
sen.e: Soseki did a lot of word games in his works like changing word order, substituting other Chinese characters for the original ones, and the like.

sen.j: 例「単簡」（簡単）、「笑談」（冗談）、「八釜しい」（やかましい）、「非道い」（ひどい）、「浪漫」（ロマン）、「沢山」（たくさん）等。

sen.j: 「新陳代謝」、「反射」、「無意識」、「価値」、「電力」、「肩が凝る」等は夏目漱石の造語である。
sen.e: Soseki coined words including '新陳代謝,' '反射,' '無意識,' '価値,' '電力,' and '肩が凝る.'

sen.j: 特に「肩こり」と呼ばれるものは日本人特有の症状であり、外国ではあまり知られていない。
sen.e: Among others, the symptom named by Soseki '肩こり' (stiff shoulders) is particularly complained by the Japanese people and not generally complained in abroad.

sen.j: 漱石が「肩が凝る」という言葉を作ったがために、多くの日本人がこの症状を自覚するようになったと言われる。
sen.e: It is said that most Japanese people became aware of the symptom when Soseki coined the word '肩が凝る' (have stiff shoulders.)

sen.j: 日本人が作った漢詩は中国語での発音を意識していないため、中国人には上手な漢詩とはされにくい。
sen.e: Since Japanese compose a Chinese-style poem without concerning its Chinese pronunciation, the Chinese-style poems made by Japanese are generally not appreciated by Chinese.
Since Japanese compose a Chinese-style poem without concerning its Chinese pronunciation, the Chinese-style poems made by Japanese are generally not appreciated by Chinese.

sen.j: だが、漱石の漢詩は中国語で発音しても美しい とされ、2006年には『中国語で聞く 夏目漱石漢詩選』（耕文社）というCDつきの書籍も出版されている。
sen.e: It is said, however, the Chinese-style poems wrote by Soseki are exceptionally beautiful in pronunciation; in 2006, these poems are published as a book "Chugokugo de kiku Natsume Soseki Kanshisen" (Kobunsha) with CD.

sen.j: 現在は吉川幸次郎『漱石詩注』が岩波文庫にある（初版は岩波新書、昭和42年）。
sen.e: Soseki's Chinese-style poems are currently available by "Soseki shichu" written by Kojiro YOSHIKAWA published by Iwanamibunko (first edition was published by Iwanamishinsho, 1967.)

sen.j: また娘婿の松岡讓が朝日新聞社で『漱石の漢詩』を1966年に出版している。
sen.e: Soseki's daughter's husband Yuzuru MATSUOKA has also published "Soseki no Kanshi" from Asahi Shinbunsha in 1966.

sen.j: 日本での絶大な名声に比較すると、海外、とりわけ欧米での知名度はそれほど高いとはいえない（中国・韓国では比較的よく知られてはいるが）。
sen.e: In contrast with his great fame in Japan, Soseki is not very famous in abroad, especially in Western countries (though, Soseki is relatively famous in China and Korea.)

sen.j: グレン・グールドはアラン・ターニーによる英訳の『草枕』を愛読しており、自らラジオ番組で朗読したことがある。
sen.e: Glenn Gould likes reading "Kusamakura" translated by Alan Turney, and recited part of the book in a radio program.

sen.j: また、スーザン・ソンタグは『Where the Stress Falls』のなかで漱石について知られざる「天才的な多芸の作家」として高く評価している。
sen.e: Susan Sontag highly evaluates Soseki NATSUME as an unknown 'talented writer of varied accomplishments' in her book "Where the Stress Falls."

sen.j: 1946年末に漱石の著作権が切れるにあたって、桜菊書院と岩波書店とがそれぞれ「漱石全集」を刊行して争った事件。
sen.e: When the copyright on Soseki's books expired at the end of 1946, both Oukikushoin and Iwanamishoten published 'Soseki Zenshu' and came into conflict with each other.
